results.justification: The document explicitly states the research investigates machine learning predictors using student logs to predict external assessment outcomes. (e.g., "In this work we investigate machine learning predictors using students’ logs during their first few hours of use with educational technology can provide useful predictive insight into those students’ end-of-school year external assessment.")

Sections 2.2.1 (Features Extraction), 2.2.2 (Predicting Outcomes using Machine Learning Methods), and 2.2.3 (Model Evaluation) provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, including data analysis and evaluation metrics.
The document does not state that the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.

The document implies data sharing is limited due to the nature of the data and context: "MATHia data used in this study was collected from 2644 students..." and similar statements suggest the data is from specific institutions and may be subject to privacy restrictions.

Section 2.1 (Data) provides descriptions of the datasets (Can’t Wait to Learn, MATHia, iReady), including the number of students, data collection periods, and the nature of the assessments. Features are described in 2.2.1.
The document describes how data was collected from each platform (e.g., log data from tablets for CWTL, data from software usage for MATHia and iReady). (Section 2.1)
The document does not state that the analysis code is shared in an open repository.
Since the code is not shared, there is no justification provided.
The document mentions data preprocessing (Section 2.2.1), but does not state that the code for this preparation is shared.

Statistical tests (5-fold cross validation), models (linear regression, support vector regression, random forest), and assumptions (e.g., projecting post-test scores to [0,1]) are clearly described (Section 2.2.2).
RMSE and R-squared (𝑅2) are reported as evaluation metrics (Section 2.2.3).
The study is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
Since there are no qualitative methods, there is no data coding or analysis to describe.
Results are presented in tables and figures (e.g., Figure 1, Tables 3-5) with clear descriptions and comparisons.

The document discusses limitations, such as the potential impact of usage time definitions (Section 2.2), the sparsity of data in CWTLReading (Section 3.2), and the need for further validation before using predictions for interventions (Section 3.6).
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
